issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case, there is a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8(1) of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, with effect from 14th April, 1943, when the business, which had previously been carried on in partnership between two Dayabhaga Hindu undivided families, was carried on by a partnership between the separated male members of the two families?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case ,there is a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8  1  of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, with effect from 14th April, 1943, when the busi-

issues.text: Whether the assessee is entitled to put forward an entirely new case that there was no change in the persons carrying on the business because it was always a partnership between individual members?

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that this is an entirely new case which is number number open to the assessee

issues.text: Whether a partnership agreement entered into by the kartas of two Hindu undivided families constitutes a partnership between the families or between the individual kartas, such that other family members do not ipso facto become partners?

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu undivided family is numberdoubt included in the expression person as defined in the Indian

arguments.claim: There has been no change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act because the firm has always been constituted by individual partners, originally the two kartas and from 17th June 1934 the sons individually.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel's contention is that the firm was originally a partnership of two Hindu undivided families represented by their respective kartas Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan and that on and from the 17th June, 1934, the sons of Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and the sons of Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan individually became partners in the firm and the firm has remained so constituted at all material times and that there has been no change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan may well have been described as a partnership between two Hindu undivided families. A Hindu undivided family is numberdoub

arguments.court_reasoning: Entirely new case not open to assessee; inconsistent with prior stands before authorities and Tribunal; no evidence to support.

arguments.claim: The assessee is entitled to carry forward deficiencies from previous years under section 7 of the Excess Profits Tax Act without restriction under section 8.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed that the total deficiencies amounting to over Rs. 84,000 carried forward from previous years up to the chargeable accounting period ending 13th April, 1943, should be added to the sum of Rs. 12,804 and the aggregate amount should be carried forward under section 7 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of this case ,there is a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 1  of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, with e

arguments.court_reasoning: Change in persons under section 8(1) occurred on 14th April 1943, limiting carry forward.

arguments.claim: There was a change in the persons carrying on the business on 14th April 1943 from two Hindu undivided families to eight individual members, triggering section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer rejected this contention on the ground that there had been a change in the persons carrying on the business and the old business should be deemed to have been discontinued and a new business to have commenced within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act and carried over only Rs. 12,804.

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmed based on facts in statement of case and documents.

arguments.claim: The assessee cannot put forward an entirely new case at the appellate stage that is inconsistent with the case made before lower authorities.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that this is an entirely new case which is not open to the assessee to put forward.

arguments.claim: The assessee is bound by the statement of case drawn up by the Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The statement of case drawn up by the Appellate Tribunal, which is binding on the assessee, clearly indicates that up to 13th April, 1943, the business was a partnership concern carried on by two Dayabhaga Hindu undivided families...

arguments.claim: A partnership between kartas of two Hindu undivided families is a partnership between the kartas personally, not the families, and other members do not become partners ipso facto.

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu undivided family is no doubt included in the expression 'person' as defined in the Indian Income-tax Act as well as in the Excess Profits Tax Act but it is not a juristic person for all purposes. The affairs of the Hindu undivided family are looked after and managed by its karta.

arguments.claim: There is no evidence that individual members were partners before 14th April 1943; documents show only two partners.

anchor.surface_text: We need not pursue this matter further, for in the case now before us there is no evidence whatever to prove that all the members of the two families had individually become partners in the business at any time before the 14th April, 1943. The documents to which reference will presently be made do not support the case now sought to be made by learned counsel for the assessee.

arguments.claim: Partnership registration applications and deeds before 1943 show only two partners: Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and sons, and Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan and sons.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2 of the Indian Income-tax Rules requires that such application shall be signed by all the partners personally... It appears that on the 19th October, 1943, an application was made on behalf of Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and sons and Bijan Kumar Sadhukhan and brothers... The last column showed that... share of Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and sons was Rs. 4,370 and that of Bijan Kumar Sadhukhan and brothers was also Rs. 4,370.

arguments.claim: The 1943 and 1944 partnership deeds indicate reconstitution into eight partners from 14th April 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The instrument of partnership dated the 19th September, 1943... Clause 6... profits... eight-annas share each... It further appears that on the 28th December, 1944, another deed... This construction of those clauses is clearly inconsistent with the fifth recital which says that on and from the 1st Baisak, 1350 B.S. i.e. 14th April, 1943, the said firm was reconstituted as constituted of eight partners.

arguments.claim: The assessee's description of partnership between members of HUFs as between HUFs does not alter the legal position of change.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the assessee maintains that there has been no variance in the case made by his client inasmuch as the partnership which, according to him, was being carried on by and between the individual members of one Hindu undivided family... may well have been described as a partnership between two Hindu undivided families.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: go behind the facts so found by the Appellate Tribunal in the statement of the case and as is implicit in the question itself, then there can be numbe

arguments.court_reasoning: HUF not juristic person; partnership by kartas is between kartas.

arguments.claim: The question referred implies prior partnership of two HUFs, disrupted, then eight individuals, leading to change.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the very question referred by the Appellate Tribunal implies... that a business was carried on by a partnership composed of two partners each of which was a Hindu undivided family, that there was a disruption of both the families and that on and after such disruption the business was carried on by a partnership entered into by and between the separated male members of the two families.

holdings.text: there had been a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Further, the very question referred by the. Appellate Tribu L B D 2SCI a  nal implies, as pointed out by the High Court, that a business was carried on by a partnership companyposed of two partners each of which was a Hindu undivided family, that there was a, disruption of both the families and that on and after such disruption the business was carried on by a partnership centered into by and between the separated male members of the two families. We also agree with the High Court that if the case of the assessee was that even before 14th April, 1943, there was a partnership of eight persons and if that case was accepted by the Appellate Tribunal then no question of law could have arisen on those facts. It is only because the fact found was that prior to 13th April, 1943, the business was carried on by a partnership of two Hindu undivided families which prima facie means a partnership between two Kartas representing two Hindu undivided families and that from 14th April, 1943, it became a business of eight individual members of two disrupted families that the question of law could arise. If, as we hold, the assessee is not entitled to go behind the facts so found by the Appellate Tribunal in the statement of the case and as is implicit in the question itself, then there can be no doubt that there had been a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act and it has not been argued otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee bound by Tribunal's statement of case showing business carried by two HUFs until 13.4.1943 then by eight individuals; documents confirm reconstitution; applies s.8(1) EPTA deeming change as discontinuance.

holdings.text: this is an entirely new case which is not open to the assessee to put forward

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsels contention is that the firm was originally a partnership of two Hindu undivided families represented by their respective kartas Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan and that on and from the 17th June, 1934, the sons of Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and the sons of Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan individually became partners in the firm and the firm has remained so constituted at all material times and that there has been no change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act. It appears to us that this is an entirely new case which is number number open to the assessee to put forward.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New contention inconsistent with assessee's prior cases before EPT Officer, AAC, and Tribunal that business was by two HUFs until disruption; first raised in s.66(1) application.

holdings.text: When two kartas of two Hindu undivided families enter into a partnership agreement the partnership is popularly described as one between the two Hindu undivided families but in the eye of the law it is a partnership between the two kartas and the other members of the families do not ipso facto become partners

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the assessee maintains that there has number been any variance in the case made by his client in- asmuch as the partnership which, according to him, was, being carried on by and between the individual members of one Hindu undivided family, namely, the four sons of Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and the individual members of another Hindu undivided family, namely, the four sons of Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan may well have been described as a partnership between two Hindu undivided families. A Hindu undivided family is numberdoubt included in the expression person as defined in the Indian Income-tax Act as well as in the Excess Profits Tax Act but it is number a juristic person for all purposes. The affairs of the Hindu undivided family are looked after and managed by its karta.

holdings.reasoning_summary: HUF included in 'person' under Acts but not juristic person for all purposes; managed by karta who represents in partnership; other members not automatically partners.

holdings.text: The statement of case drawn up by the Appellate Tribunal, which is binding on the assessee, clearly indicates that up to 13th April, 1943, the business was a partnership concern carried on by two Dayabhaga Hindu undivided families

anchor.surface_text: Further, the statement of case drawn up by the Appellate Tribunal, which is binding on the assessee, clearly indicates that up to 13th April, 1943, the business was a partnership concern carried on by two Dayabhaga Hindu undivided families and that it was after that date that the eight members of the two families constituted themselves into a partnership.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties bound by facts stated in Tribunal's reference statement of case; cannot go behind it.

holdings.text: in the case now before us there is no evidence whatever to prove that all the members of the two families had individually become partners in the business at any time before the 14th April, 1943. The documents to which reference will presently be made do not support the case now sought to be made

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, nothing to prevent the individual members of one Hindu undivided family from entering into a partnership with the individual members of another Hindu undivided family and in such a case it is a partnership between the individual members and it is wholly inappropriate to describe such a partnership as one between two Hindu undivided families. We need not pursue this matter further, for in the case now before us there is no evidence whatever to prove that all the members of the two families had individually become partners in the business at any time before the 14th April, 1943.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Registration applications, returns, and deeds before 1943 list only two partners (Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan & sons, Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan & sons); 1943 deed shows reconstitution into eight.

holdings.text: the very question referred by the Appellate Tribunal implies that a business was carried on by a partnership composed of two partners each of which was a Hindu undivided family, that there was a disruption of both the families and that on and after such disruption the business was carried on by a partnership entered into by and between the separated male members of the two families

anchor.surface_text: If the firm was before 1st Baisak, 1350 B.S., constituted of eight partners then there could be no occasion for reciting that the firm was reconstituted as constituted of eight partners. Further, the statement of case drawn up by the Appellate Tribunal, which is binding on the assessee, clearly indicates that up to 13th April, 1943, the business was a partnership concern carried on by two Dayabhaga Hindu undivided families...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Framed question presupposes prior partnership of two HUFs disrupted then eight individuals, triggering s.8 change.

anchor.surface_text: We also agree with the High Court that if the case of the assessee was that even before 14th April, 1943, there was a partnership of eight persons and if that case was accepted by the Appellate Tribunal then numberquestion of law companyld have arisen on those facts. It is only because the fact found was that prior to 13th April, 1943, the business was carried on by a partnership of two Hindu undivided families which prima facie means a partnership between two Kartas representing two Hindu undivided families and that from 14th April, 1943, it became a business of eight individual members of two disrupted families that the question of law companyld arise. If, as we hold, the assessee is number entitled to go behind the facts so found by the Appellate Tribunal in the statement of the case and as is implicit in the question itself, then there can be numberdoubt that there had been a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act and it has number been argued otherwise.

outcome.relief_summary: Court upheld finding of change in persons carrying on business under section 8 of Excess Profits Tax Act; assessee's contention rejected, no carry forward of pre-change deficiencies

anchor.surface_text: We also agree with the High Court that if the case of the assessee was that even before 14th April, 1943, there was a partnership of eight persons and if that case was accepted by the Appellate Tribunal then numberquestion of law companyld have arisen on those facts. It is only because the fact found was that prior to 13th April, 1943, the business was carried on by a partnership of two Hindu undivided families which prima facie means a partnership between two Kartas representing two Hindu undivided families and that from 14th April, 1943, it became a business of eight individual members of two disrupted families that the question of law companyld arise. If, as we hold, the assessee is number entitled to go behind the facts so found by the Appellate Tribunal in the statement of the case and as is implicit in the question itself, then there can be numberdoubt that there had been a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act and it has number been argued otherwise.
